commentBody:
(Second attempt.)

I noticed that Deb steered away from the spot that I'm sure will generate most of the complaints today.  

Even if you were totally familiar with [Comedian Glaser], you might still not be sure if she spells it NIKKI or Nicki.  

And if you weren't into skateboarding culture, it would be possible to guess that the trick mentioned could be called a "facie" rather than a FAKIE.  Either one of them sounds ridiculous to me, but somehow I intuited the right one.  Maybe FAKIE sounds just a tad less ridiculous...

Of all the crosses I've seen in recent memory, this one seems closest to me to what Rex Parker originally meant when he coined the term "Natick", even if the skateboarding term isn't actually a proper noun.  Neither answer is easily inferrable, and they cross in just the wrong place.

I(didn’t)NEEDAHINT to complete this one.  I started slowly, but soon found a mess of clues that were in my wheelhouse, like PINACOLDA and WETMARTINI sitting side by side, and a variety of music related clues including a sublime Mozart ARIA. I did get fooled a bit by trying boas instead of BOTS for Amazon nuisances.  I liked the clue for ONEMANBAND and I liked ZEROTOHERO just for itself.  Fun puzzle over too soon.

13 day streak now, thought I was going to lose it today. ONEMANBAND was what turned the corner for me. Took a while to get there, but only a minute to close it out once I did. That whole NE corner got me good

I, too, laughed at ONE MAN BAND. Great clue, and it evoked the amazing almost-centagenarian Dick Van Dyke in Mary Poppins. Haven't seen it? Here it is: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6OwnBuPbMqc Fun and fabulous Friday - now on to the weekend!

Wow! I don't know why I loved this one so much, but it just hit the spot for me. Hard enough to feel meaty (I had to work on the top two quadrants for a few minutes to get them to fall into place), but smooth enough to feel fair and delightful. As a lover of Spelling Bee, I'm always gratified to see NENE show up in context.  PWNED and ZEROTOHERO were favorites of mine (and the latter has now put me in the mood to watch Disney's Hercules).
I had ice pack before gel pack and it threw me off. Once I got through to the correct first three letters I had an easier time with the nw corner. Enjoyable Friday puzzle. Happy birthday to me today

Not bad.

Fewer black squares than normal makes for decent fill, but this was still easier than a Friday should be.

7/10

A quick Friday for me, with my hangup being the one mentioned by Steve L earlier. Let's just say that my orthopod would probably get a lot of business if I took up skateboarding, and I don't know the terminology unless I see it here several times; and I don't know Ms. Glaser at all.

Other than that, despite the fear of all the white space, I started filling things in fairly readily. Eels, then BOaS, before BOTS, but then the NW filled in as I recognized a new clue for an old friend. I thought briefly, I NEED A HINT, but I got through the rest of it with not much difficulty other than that already mentioned, and ended up with some TIME TO KILL.

Thanks, Colin, it was a fun puzzle.
Good puzzle. I enjoyed it. Impressed with myself that I actually knew the word pwned.
14 minutes 3 seconds. Can the great Barry Ancona match that?? I hope to hear forthwith. Godspeed ye lonely souls and may the Saturday puzzle be a punishing and natick-filled grid!
HOE cake and WET martini- egad! For a truly strong flavour try Kendal Mint Cake, beloved of fell hikers.

Woo-hoo, a 300-day-streak! Just two more months and change before the big, once unimaginable milestone.

Loved today's puzzle too. Fridays might be my favorite now that the novelty of Thursday/Sunday tricks has worn off.

I think I disagree with Steve L that NIKKI/FAKIE is a Natick, just because FAKIE is (even to somebody like me, who has never seen or heard of it, and who is more likely to learn to fly than to ever do it) so much more likely to be the right answer than FAcIE. If nothing else, FAcIE would probably be clued via "prima facie". In a true Natick, at teast for me, several letters are equally likely if you don't know at least one of the two answers.

On the bright side "made an impression" was clever though it doesn't seem likely it's original?  And it was nice to see SWAK again; it's been a long time.

Fast Friday, fairly fun.

Tough one for me. But a good one. Maybe if there were just a couple more clues that could be more confidently answered on an empty grid, besides the trivia (which I never seem to get). Even after the hints provided here, ended up with a completely barren NW corner, gave up and started Googling. For sure, INEEDAHINT.

People do not still use that initialism, generally. I'm overstating things, of course, because something like that will never totally disappear. It's a little too cute/romantic for that. I'm sure there are plenty of people that do indeed still use it in its original capacity, and I would guess those people are likely over-represented in the nytimes crossword comments section. 

Just googling, there was apparently an NCIS episode in 2005 called SWAK. There are a variety of companies/products called SWAK, some using the original initialism, others where it stands for something else. 

If you look at google n-grams, it's quite rare, way down from its peak in 1805. Google search trends only go back to 2004, and are only reported as percentages compared to their peak year within the date range. It's currently at <25% of its 2011 peak google search popularity (USA), which I'm sure was itself quite low in absolute terms, especially because that data will be "polluted" by foreign language speakers in the US searching for terms in their language. 

"Swak" appears to be a word in Tagalog, and there was a Filipino news show called "Swak na Swak". It is also a word or word-root or place name in Namibia. Those two countries (and to a lesser extent, South Africa) account for the vast majority of worldwide google searches of "swak." US searches for "swak" were only 6% as frequent as searches from the Philippines.

Great puzzle, just the right amount of freshness for a Friday night. 

I want to say how much I appreciate this group — it is a good place, full of warmth and goodwill. 

Also. I think I just completed the archive — 11,227 puzzles as of tonight. An excellent form of therapy, crosswords and the Spelling Bee have made every day better and helped me through the tougher days. There is of course an endless supply of fresh puzzles elsewhere, but it’s not the same.

Thanks to everyone who contributes to this excellent community.

I went tripping through the grid, BARHOPPING like a puzzle wizard, top here, bottom there, middle filling in, thrilled when I knew CORINTH and I didn't NEEDAHINT, getting tipsy with the proximity of a PINACOLADA and a WETMARTINI going down on the same page, wowed by the cheekiness of the ubiquitous biscuit hogging ten consecutive squares, then somehow got bogged down and didn't have the MIENS to wind it up.  Felt like a ZERO HERO, with no upward progress  until I pried my stubborn brain off some lousy fills and wound it up at 46:06, a joke for the real puzzle dazzlers, but I hope respectable enough for the C- or a D+ of an average human being.  

Cool puzzle, Colin Adams. I hope putting all this together wasn't too taxing and left you some TIMETOKILL MANSCAPING. Thanks! ( I think I'll have a drink now, and it won't be milk with you-know-what. )
Pogon does not mean beard in Latin - I believe the etymology for that is Greek. As barba means beard in Latin, as barbarian literally means bearded one.

Turns out NIcKI was actually NIKKI, and FAcIE wasn't a skateboard slang adapted from the word "face". I still solved it without hints or lookups in a comfortable half hour, so I think American solvers definitely had an easy one today!

A toast to the Rescue Answer, that St. Bernard that saves you amidst a sea of white.  There you are, lost in a sizeable area of the grid, not certain of any answer so far, with few left to go, and suddenly you hit the R.A. – the answer you know, and the longer the better – which breaks that empty mass open. ZERO TO HERO in a blink.  Here’s to you, R.A., for the smiles you bring.  

In the box today with its chunks o’ white in the corners and sash, those Rescue Answers made several visitations, resulting in “Whee!”-filled splats, and let me tell you, that charges up the spirit.

Oh, the grid held beauty (TIME TO KILL, I KID, ONE MAN BAND, SCAVENGE), freshness (six answer debuts and seven only-once-befores), and the lovely STEP up from the bottom – and I’m grateful to Colin for a fun and satisfying fill-in.  Thank you, sir!

I extend that gratitude to the Rescue Answer, bringer of jubilation.  You are my Crosslandia friend for life.

I’ve been a subscriber for years and kept my crossword subscription in a time of horrific rising antisemitism because it seemed separate. Is the NYT crossword now an actively hostile place to anyone who cares about antisemitism and racism, and a place that normalizes glorification of the Holocaust as something that should be repeated??? If so, please let me know so I can cancel my subscription, I don’t even want to open it any more knowing I should apparently gird myself for horrifically casual normalization of antisemitism.

Over much too quickly, 
but that leads me to a question.

Has anyone else played around with
solving patterns and found 
*distinct*
differences in the solving experience,
based on your pattern/system?

I see comments about not getting much 
“on the first pass* 
which baffles me.

Do you read the clues and fill in
what you’re certain is true,
and then go back and look at the crosses
and the grid?

I think that would take
forrrreverrrr.

I don’t solve with a timer,
and prefer a longer time with my dear puzzle,
but I simply cannot see the clues as the
starting point.

My brain can only see areas.
Zones. Blocks. Corners.
And I solve them one by one as they
lead into each other.

I *think* it’s far easier that way.

Am I solving  [gulp] *wrong*?

I know there’s no right/wrong, but
the clue-led solve just seems so very
awkward and confusing to me!

Please 🙏 explain it to me like I’m five..?

While the "wet" or "dry" aspect primarily focuses on vermouth, the olive plays a supporting role that can enhance or alter the drink. Here's how it relates:

Classic Dry Martini:
Often uses a standard Manzanilla olive, which provides a familiar salty counterpoint to the dry, spirit-forward nature of the drink.
The goal is often to keep the olive's flavor relatively neutral, allowing the gin or vodka to shine.
Wet Martini:
With its increased vermouth content, a wet martini has a slightly softer, more herbal profile.
Here, some might choose a slightly more flavorful olive, like a Queen or Castelvetrano, to complement the vermouth's botanicals.
The milder nature of the wet martini can handle a more pronounced olive flavor.
Dirty Martini:
This variation introduces olive brine into the cocktail, significantly changing the flavor.
In a dirty martini, the olive itself becomes less about subtle flavor nuances and more about reinforcing the briny character of the drink.
Therefore, the olive used in a dirty martini is very important, because the brine that it is contained in, is added to the drink.

I noticed that Deb steered away from the spot that I'm sure will generate most of the complaints today.  

Even if you were totally familiar with [Comedian Glaser], you might still not be sure if she spells it NIKKI or Nicki.

Yes, pogon (πώγων) is beard in Greek. Interestingly, Seneca and Pliny the Elder used it to coin a term for bearded comets: pogoniae. Pliny writes in his Natural History:

“Pogoniae sunt, quae a capite lumen spargunt in modum barbae.” 

Pogoniae are those [comets] that scatter light from the head like a beard.

@Sam Lyons *Pogonia* is a genus of plants within the Orchid family, distinguished by the "beard" on the lower petal, the "lip" or "labellum" (soul patch?). There's also a genus of marine fish, *Pogonias*, and of lizards, native to Australia, *Pogona*, which are sometimes kept as pets: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pogona#In_captivity Beards, all.

Yeah, I think @spurious is correct.  

A standard martini contains a "bit" or "splash" of vermouth.  A dry martini has less vermouth.

Now, one of the most famous old time bar orders was a dry martini, dry as the Sahara, so dry that water molecules are terrified to be anywhere in the area.  But all that means is "no vermouth".  It's not like you can add anti-vermouth to move to a drier than dry state.

Martinis do have a lot of variations for such a simple drink--gin and vermouth (old style martinis, not vodka martinis).  It's a dirty martini if you use an onion as a garnish.  I think there are other variations.  

(At one point I was thinking about ditching programming to be a bartender, and I am a proud alumnus of the Minnesota School of Bartending.)

@Jay Pwned is a misspelling of "owned."  Gamers often typed it so quickly that it frequently got misspelled as "pwned" and then became its own word. A noob is someone new to a game, so in the clue it's a signal that you want gaming vocabulary.  Source:  I have teenagers.

Noob is a phonetic misspelling of newb, which is short for newbie.

 As info the last video game I played was Space Invaders by Atari, ha ha.

@Jay and another layer of computer nerdiness: noob is spelled with zeros instead of Os. Passwords often include numbers instead of letters, m1k3 instead of mike, and that of course spills out into online chats.

@Nora 

Also, some 25 years ago 1337 5p34k (that's "leet speak" written with numbers, leet being derived from "elite") was popular among gamers, which may have spawned the n00b spelling.

@Jay Pwned, which rhymes with "owned" is gamer slang for "I owned your *ss." (or I trounced you).  Noobs (or n00bs) are newbies, or new gamers trying to figure things out. It's also used as a mild insult when a more experienced gamer gets pwned.  I don't play video games, but my husband and 5 kids are all active gamers.

@June and “noob”the interesting thing is that it comes from newbie…a cute way to call someone new at something in game.

Yes, that's more or less what I do.  In addition, when I don't know an Across on the first pass, I'll look at the Downs whose first letters it contains and fill in that letter if I know the Down.   (I hope that makes sense!)

@CCNY 

I think that if you always solve the puzzles on-line, not on paper, and especially if you are going for speed, it's quicker and simpler to just go through all the across clues in a first pass, before going back to look at the crossing clues/answers. No scrolling up and down and back and forth through the clues.

I can't do it that way myself, I've tried. To me that's like just doing a quiz on a long word list, not a crossword puzzle. A crossword puzzle's beauty and integrity depends on the crossing of answers.

But I see the appeal of doing all the acrosses (or all the downs) in one swoop, and avoiding all the scrolling to check if the crossing answers fit.

@CCNY 
I am a solver that starts at 1A and works my way through the acrosses first. It's a little methodical, but direct. 

If the puzzle is especially tricky, then I switch up my tactics and focus on one section, switching between across and down clues.

I think both methods are valid, I don't know which is more effective. I probably depends on personal preferences.
@CCNY I do acrosses first, then downs. If the clue is plural, I put S as the last letter. If past tense, it's likely ED. if a word ends in ION, I put in T before it. Helps me a little, anyway...

@CCNY 

Solving wrong? Solving WRONG? There is no such thing. You are your only audience, critic, judge, ref. You, and no one but you, can judge your performance, ability, execution, and final grade. 

Do you have fun? A+.  Oh, sorry, not my business to tell you that. You decide!

I gave up watching the timer because I, too, like my puzzles to last. Today's went faster than usual, mostly because I am in a bit of a hurry. It's volunteer day (Mondays and Fridays at the ER). But I do a bit of both...start with the clues on Across, then down, then fill in. But if one area on Across starts to fill in, I'll stay there and finish the block. Or, if the theme presents itself early, I'll work that first. 

On Fridays, if I'm really stuck, I might try the "easy mode" or else I'll leave it until I come home later and spend my evening with it. I love hard puzzles that teach me something.

@CCNY 

I am not a speed solver, but I don't mind solving quickly as long as I don't feel like I am rushing.  On beginning of the week puzzles, I make a first pass of the across and downs without stopping to dwell on any answer, and then go back and start building on the areas where words have more than one letter filled.  Later week puzzles I may do a quick first pass, but I may also stop if I think an answer I thought of has a good chance of being right, and will try and verify that with a crossing clue.

@CCNY of course it depends! On the puzzle, on my mood, etc. Usually I go through the across in order, then the downs in order. Lots of people do first pass with only answers they are pretty sure of. Not me, I fill in any answer I have an inkling about. Works for me. After first pass I work on zones. Usually.

@CCNY Both methods are viable, in my opinion.  I'm largely clue-focused early in the week (essentially speed-running the easy puzzles—I do love my 5-minute Mondays), but from about Wed-Thu onward I find that crossfill becomes much more important (and, critically, more fun) to engage with.

@CCNY love all the replies. I always start with the acrosses, but get side tracked as I see things, and end up all over the place. 
As for the timer, I have it on, but don't think about it. It's meaningless, as I often get distracted by "life".

@CCNY - Generally speaking, I start in the upper left, working both Acrosses and Downs, and travel clockwise around the puzzle, leaving blank anything that doesn't come immediately to mind. I return on subsequent passes to fill in the holes.

The Pogonophora, for most of my career, were considered a phylum of animals. They're called the "beard worms" and included the giant tube worms that are found at the deep-sea hydrothermal vents.
